name: Yerevan
fun_fact: Fun fact: Dolmama restaurant was featured on Anthony Bourdain's Parts Unknown when System of a Down's Serj Tankian took him thereâ€”the restaurant has been perfecting dolma since 1998 and serves 8 different varieties, making it the dolma temple of the Caucasus.

hero_dishes.name: Dolma at Dolmama
hero_dishes.description: Grape leaves stuffed with spiced ground beef and rice, served with tangy yogurtâ€”tender, herbaceous, and Armenia's signature dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dolmama opened in 1998 with a mission to showcase Eastern Armenian cuisine. They offer 8 different dolma varieties including grape leaves, cabbage, peppers, and eggplant. Anthony Bourdain ate here with Serj Tankian, cementing its legendary status
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Dolmama (Pushkin Street 10â€”open daily 11am-11:30pm), Tavern Yerevan, or Sherep Restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Khorovats (Armenian BBQ)
hero_dishes.description: Grilled meat (pork, lamb, or chicken) marinated in pomegranate and herbs, cooked over charcoalâ€”smoky, juicy, and essential
hero_dishes.origin_story: Khorovats is sacred in Armenia. Proshyan Street is literally called 'Barbecue Street' where restaurants specialize in nothing but grilled meat. The charcoal smoke, lavash bread, and fresh herbs create the ultimate Armenian meal
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Proshyan Street ('Barbecue Street'), Dolmama, Tavern Yerevan, or Lavash Restaurant (where you watch lavash baked in a tandoor)

hero_dishes.name: Lavash Bread
hero_dishes.description: Thin flatbread baked in a clay tandoor ovenâ€”charred, smoky, and used to wrap khorovats or scoop up food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lavash Restaurant bakes lavash right in front of guests in a traditional tandoor. This bread is so culturally important it's on UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage list. Armenians use it for everything
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lavash Restaurant (tandoor baking on display), Dolmama, or any traditional Armenian restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Kyufta
hero_dishes.description: Armenian meatballs made from finely ground beef, shaped into dumplings and simmered in brothâ€”silky, delicate, almost ethereal
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kyufta requires serious skill: the meat is pounded until it becomes a paste, then shaped into smooth orbs. Tavern Yerevan serves the best version, cooked until tender in savory broth
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tavern Yerevan, Sherep Restaurant, or traditional Armenian taverns

signature_drinks.name: Armenian Brandy (Ararat, Noy)
signature_drinks.description: Smooth, amber-colored brandy aged in oak barrelsâ€”Armenia's most famous export after lavash
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Armenians are fiercely proud of their brandy, which Winston Churchill reportedly drank daily. Served neat in snifters after dinner, often with dried fruits and nuts. Ararat is the iconic brand

signature_drinks.name: Tan (Yogurt Drink)
signature_drinks.description: Salty, tangy yogurt drink mixed with water and herbsâ€”refreshing and meant to aid digestion
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served cold with meals, especially khorovats. The saltiness balances rich grilled meats. Every Armenian grandmother makes her own version

food_culture_notes: Dolma is so central to Armenian identity that restaurants serve 8+ varieties (grape leaves, cabbage, peppers, eggplant)
Khorovats (BBQ) is a weekend ritualâ€”families spend Sundays grilling on Proshyan Street
Lavash is UNESCO-protected and used instead of plates to scoop up food
Armenian cuisine is the ancestor of Middle Eastern foodâ€”techniques like grilling and stuffing vegetables spread from here

landmarks: Mount Ararat view from the city (though it's in Turkey)
unique_modern: Dolmama's Anthony Bourdain/Serj Tankian fame (Parts Unknown episode)
Proshyan Street as dedicated BBQ street
Lavash UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage status
Armenian brandy rivaling French cognac in worldwide acclaim
